p: Lutzomyia intermedia was shown to be the more tropical of the two species, with its climatic niche being defined by higher annual mean temperatures, lower temperature seasonality and sometimes higher precipitation seasonality (Fig. 1). In contrast, L. neivai was shown to be more subtropical, and diapause [ 4] might allow it to survive very high-temperature seasonality sometimes associated with lower precipitation seasonality. The ability of L. intermedia to survive in warmer and more humid environments than L. neivai was previously suggested [ 28]. Differences in latitudinal ranges explain the predicted responses of the two species to climate change, with the tropical L. intermedia mostly contracting its range (Fig. 6), and the subtropical L. neivai mostly shifting its range southwards (Fig. 7). This is a common difference between tropical and subtropical species, probably resulting from their adaptations to natural climate change in previous geological periods [ 43].
